summary: Biography of controversial World War II hero General George S. Patton. The film covers his wartime activities and accomplishments, beginning with his entry into the North African campaign and ending with his removal from command after his outspoken criticism of US post-war military strategy.

With one of the most iconic opening shots in cinematic history, Patton is a semi-biopic wrapped into a war movie featuring a phenomenal, dynamic performance. George C. Scott plays our titular character, a man not only born to be a general of massive armies and epic battles, but a man (re)born to be said general. What I loved about General Patton was how interesting of a man he was — he knew history (military history, at least), believed in reincarnation, he was surprisingly charming, and spoke French. He was multilayered; a curmudgeon (and that's putting it lightly) sometimes, a sympathetic "fish out of water" at others. The "Russian Army" scene portrays both his irascibility and charm back-to-back, in the blink of an eye. We also see the general's dark side when, after looking out on a field of fresh corpses (both American and German), he says to those within earshot, "My God, I love it." Had the general gotten his way, he would've taken the 3rd Army straight across Eastern Europe to the walls of the Kremlin. The film is full of practical effect battle scenes and gorgeous shots of the various locales Patton and his troops encountered, even if most of the scenes in North Africa and Sicily were actually shot in Spain. The movie is almost three hours long, but I can't think of too much, if anything, I would cut. I also enjoyed that even during the 1940s, during the height of American involvement in WWII, the media were complete and total bastards — times don't change. Patton won Best Pic, Best Director, and Best Actor at the 43rd Academy Awards, to which George C. Scott famously rejected his very merited Oscar (which he stated beforehand), calling the whole charade "a goddamn meat parade" — times don't change. Start it for that big ass flag, stay for Scott. George S. Patton was one of the greatest World War II generals of American history, so it stands to reason that a biopic around him would prove to be successful in 1970. While not a film about his life entirely, Patton follows the beloved foul-mouthed military man (George C. Scott) during the battles of Kasserine Pass, El Guettar, and the Bulge. Much like Lawrence of Arabia, the movie also focuses on the cumulous points of view on General Patton, declaring him insane and over-his-head. Unlike David Lean's masterpiece where T.E. Lawrence had a balanced and clean persona, Franklin Schaffner's demonstrates Patton's blood-soaked, hard, iron fist, making the controversial viewpoints more credible. Also, unlike Lawrence, Patton's incidents on-screen historically happened, such as shooting the mules on his trip to Messina, a handful of smacking casualties' faces and threats to execute them for their cowardice. It's unbelievable to see a film based on a well-respected general to be that brutal, yet fascinating for its honesty. However in the grand scheme of things, there are a handful of artistic liberties taken with Patton. For instance, General Patton never wore all these medals during the opening speech. While on the subject, the dialect of that speech is toned down so the movie would become more accessible and avoid an R rating. However, those don't halt Patton's reputation as one of the best war films and biography films ever made.

It seems misleading to say Patton is a biography of General George S. Patton; that might lead one to expect a film that tells the story of the man's life from childhood to death, and that isn't what Franklin J. Schaffner's award-winning movie does. Rather, the story concerns Patton's role during World War II between 1943 and 1945 (it ends some months short of his death), whilst the plot is entirely about his personality and his attitude to – or rather relationship with – war. The film is focalised through Patton to the exclusion of almost everything else: he appears in the vast majority of scenes, and those in which he doesn't appear feature other people talking about him.  Thus, the film isn't so much about Patton's life, but rather Patton the man.
And it is Patton the man as depicted here that is the key to the film's success. Partly this is due to the script: co-written by Francis Ford Coppola and Edmund H. North (who, remarkable, never actually met until they received the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay), it exercises some artistic license to take the facts and myths about Patton's career and from them create a fascinating character. Patton as depicted here is endless fascinating: he lives for war and positively revels in it, at one actually admitting as much whilst seemingly aware that this sets him apart from his fellow soldiers. He leads his men from the front, or at least much closer to it that most officers at that time did. Whether this is bravery or insanity is hard to say: the writers neatly contrast him with British General Montgomery, whose careful planning and caution is juxtaposed with Patton's recklessness and desire to steal glory for himself. Impressively, the script makes Patton look as irresponsible as he is heroic: his superiors are not impressed by his selective interpretation of his orders on Sicily and his claims that he simply wants to stop Montgomery from monopolising the war glory sounds exactly like the weak justification for risking his men's lives that it is.
This, almost paradoxically, is what makes the character of Patton so interesting. Whilst undoubtedly impressive in many respects, he is profoundly flawed in others.  His belief that he is a reincarnation of past warriors makes him seem delusional, raising questions about whether such a man should be in command. His judgement is demonstrably flawed, such as when he accidentally insults Britain and America's Russian allies whilst giving a speech in England. He is pragmatically brutal, whether he's telling his men to make the enemy die for his country or callously shooting two mules and having them dragged out of his men's way whilst their owner looks on aghast. And most memorably, his career is briefly derailed when he viciously slaps a serviceman and has him thrown out of a field hospital, denouncing the man's shell-shock as cowardice; Patton is not portrayed as a man who understands or empathises with mental illness and although he is later forced to apologise, it sounds hollow.  Patton may be an American hero, but he was also an egomaniac and a self-confessed warmonger.
The fact that in spite of this the audience is inclined to both like and sympathise with him is due largely to the performance of George C. Scott. A Hollywood maverick who famously refused to accept his Academy Award for Best Actor, Scott wasn't Schaffner's first choice as leading man, but it is now impossible to imagine anyone else in the role. Scott was a Method actor of sorts who meticulously researched the role, and he completely immerses himself in it to the extent that a member of the production crew later recalled that at times he thought he was Patton. The result is utterly convincing and he makes Patton simultaneously larger than life and also entirely human. His fit of rage when he slaps the serviceman is terrifyingly convincing; so too is his humility and contrition later in the film when he practically begs his former subordinate and now commanding officer Bradley to give him a command. Scott makes Patton seem sympathetic, his respect for his enemy Rommel seeming impressively noble, his rivalry with Montgomery almost mischievous, and his disappointment in his rather meek dog endearing. 
Schaffner allows Scott to dominate the film, right from the unforgettable opening monologue in which Patton address both his men and the audience from in front of a huge American flag. It is a speech that Scott refused to give until the director lied to him and told him it would be included at the end of the film, since he felt that it would overshadow the rest of his performance; it doesn't, but he's so mesmerising whilst delivering it that one can understand why he was worried. Schaffner never allows the other cast members to come close to overshadowing Scott: there are some fine actors here, most notably Karl Michael Vogler as Rommel, Michael Bates as Montgomery and – especially – Karl Malden as Bradley, but whilst none of them puts a foot wrong, their characters are written such that they only ever serve to hold up a mirror to that of Patton.
In all respects, Patton is an accomplished of filmmaking: the cinematography makes the carnage of battle almost picturesque, for example during Patton's defeat of Rommel's forces at Battle of El Guettar, and the film looks glorious, thanks in no small part to its locations. Jerry Goldsmith's Oscar-nominated soundtrack is also a triumph, by turns rousing and oddly unsettling. But despite the copious talents of everybody involved, Patton will always be remembered first and foremost as George C. Scott's greatest performance, and rightly so.

George S. Patton, George C. Scott, is a mad, war hungry general who leads the United States military American II Corps from 1943 to 1945 as they face off against the German army lead by Erwin Rommel, Karl Michael Vogler. He faces harsh repercussions for his questionable actions such as slapping a crying soldier and ordering he report to the front line but his love for war remains his motivation throughout and he is held back by nothing in being present and in power during the battles. The Germans nervously speculate about him as his myth becomes more popular but he is undeterred by human adversaries.

My biggest issue with the film was that the character that the film focuses all of it's attention upon isn't particularly deep, he loves war more than anything else, and yet we are forced to spend three hours with him as this one point is continuously reinforced. The film would have been wise to settle on a tone as well as I assumed from the comedic tone of the first scene that the film was a satire and yet we were meant to feel genuinely sorry for Patton as he laments the fact that he can't participate in war. The film doesn't make any real comment or have any perspective on Patton as a figure or the implications of war. When considering that Francis Ford Coppola wrote this I expected something with even a fraction of the brilliance of Apocalypse Now (1979) but this was missing all of the dark humor and horror that made that film such a definitive statement on the Vietnam War. 

I think Patton would have been entertaining if he were a supporting character in a film from the perspective of another character. At his best moments he felt like something out of Catch-22 but Scott's enjoyable but one note performance becomes tiresome after we spend over an hour with him, a little bit of Scott goes a long way but too much of him can be fatal. Great satires like Nashville (1975) know to use their most eccentric characters sparingly as Geraldine Chaplin's Opal appears briefly but gets some of the funniest and deceptively meaningful lines in the film. Patton could have been used similarly as a symbol of all that's absurd about war and the people who can't live without it, I would have been perfectly happy with Scott winning the Best Supporting Actor Academy Award for fifteen minutes of screen time. 

The impressive part of the film is the opening scene as you get the stunning, memorable image of a pristine American flag and a defiant, militant Patton saluting a rapt audience. His opening monologue is fantastic as he spits out the sort of lines you would expect from Robert Duvall in Apocalypse Now (1979) and Scott gets a chance to unleash that iconic voice so full of anger and vitriol. I was amazed by the very brief moment and throughout I admired the cinematography, attention to period detail and the choreography and shooting of the battle scenes but I just didn't care about any of the people involved.

I'd say that Five Easy Pieces (1970) was the deserving Best Picture winner of the films nominated against Patton because it's an intimate character study that teaches you something about the main character whilst also being consistently entertaining. I also believe that Melvyn Douglas should have won the Academy Award for Best Actor instead of Scott. Watch the first five minutes of the film and then stop because the rest of the film's not worth the time.

Seeing someone so obsessed with all of the antiquated benefits of war (i.e. glory, exhilaration, and fulfillment in the face of death) honestly does make for a complicated watch. You as an audience member really do end up both pitying and disliking Patton in equal measure. And though I can't necessarily justify the overall length, it still is an unquestionably fascinating experience at times.

The film opens with Scott's rendering of Patton's speech to the Third Army, set against a huge American flag. Coppola and North had to tone down Patton's actual words and statements in the scene, as well as throughout the rest of the film, to avoid an R rating; in the opening monologue, the word "fornicating" replaced "fucking" when he was criticizing The Saturday Evening Post. Also, Scott's gravelly and scratchy voice is the opposite of Patton's high-pitched, nasal and somewhat squeaky voice, a point noted by historian S.L.A. Marshall. However, Marshall also points out that the film contains "too much cursing and obscenity [by Patton]. Patton was not habitually foul-mouthed. He used dirty words when he thought they were needed to impress."

When Scott learned that the speech would open the film, he refused to do it, as he believed that it would overshadow the rest of his performance. Director Schaffner assured him that it would be shown at the end. The scene was shot in one afternoon at Sevilla Studios in Madrid, with the flag having been painted on the back of the stage wall.

All the medals and decorations shown on Patton's uniform in the monologue are replicas of those actually awarded to Patton. However, the general never wore all of them in public and was in any case not a four-star general at the time he made the famous speeches on which the opening is based. He wore them all on only one occasion, in his backyard in Virginia at the request of his wife, who wanted a picture of him with all his medals. The producers used a copy of this photo to help recreate this "look" for the opening scene.





The film was shot in 65mm Dimension 150 by cinematographer Fred J. Koenekamp and has a music score by Jerry Goldsmith.

Patton won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture.

The opening monologue, delivered by George C. Scott as General Patton with an enormous American flag behind him, remains an iconic and often quoted image in film. The film was successful, and in 2003, Patton was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically or aesthetically significant".

Review In A Nutshell:

Patton is an excellent film that captures the essence of the titular character. Let me just get this out of the way and say that, before seeing this, I didn't know who General Patton was and what he has achieved. I came into this film like an empty vessel and letting the film shape my perspective of the character and what I got was certainly satisfying.

The film shows us that Patton was a driven man; he wanted to be ranked up there along with the notable names in the history of war. It also shows us his life values and his expectations from his soldiers in order to win the war. This character and his story could have been an easy person to hate, as we are given sides of him that weren't exactly pleasing to watch, like his verbal abuse towards his soldiers and his rebellious nature, but Coppola and North, the film's writers, handled his story in such a way that maintains our sense of sympathy towards him. They let us in deep with the character in order for us to completely understand his actions.

I was also happy to find that the film avoids heavy sentimentality as similarly crafted films and subjects tend to be dampened in order to manipulate our feelings towards the characters. I am not the easiest person to convince when it comes to war films as it takes me awhile to understand the non-fictional aspects and thematic concerns, but Patton was handled beautifully ensuring that it is more about the character rather than the situation, allowing the film to feel accessible.

Schaffner allows the film to slowly build, comprehensively explore the titular character in order to have its third act feel more impacting. This film has also got me interested in trying out other films from Franklin J. Schaffner, hoping maybe they would be just as powerful as this film.

The film's photography was impressive, giving us the glimpse of war through the eyes of the general and as a strategist; we see the fight at a distance, with only a couple of moments where it gets close to the action. The film also captures the drama of the film well, though there were a couple of moments where the shot felt too distant from the character and felt it needed a sense of intimacy.

Patton featured a strong musical score by the legendary Jerry Goldsmith, who I adore for his work on Ridley Scott's Alien. The score was both patriotic and dramatic, and one of the key components in making this character come to life.

The film featured a worthy performance from George C. Scott, playing this man who is thick as ice in his exterior but also contains a slight interior vulnerability. I think my adoration for his performance would grow even further the more times I come back to this film. I wasn't able to focus so much on the rest of the cast, as I felt this film was a clear one man show.

Patton is a film that almost won me over completely. If it weren't for its minor issues, I would have most likely added this to my list of Great Movies, but I think this film is headed to that direction anyways, all it needs is another viewing. Simply put, Patton is a powerful film.

The definitive biopic.  Based off Ladislas Farago's Patton: Ordeal and Triumph, and Omar Bradley's A Soldier's Story, Patton follows the life of US General George S. Patton during World War II, where he causes controversy while trying to strengthen his troops.  The biopic helped lay the groundwork for all biopics good and bad (why are there bad ones?  Are people this disrespectful to this person or something when they don't portray their life accurately in film?) by following the most significant events in the person's life that helped define them for who they are, and executing the events with finesse, which includes intelligence and emotion for a much-needed human feel.  Francis Ford Coppola and Edmund H. North are able to respect Patton while also keeping the historical accuracy intact.  Franklin J. Schaffer is able to capture the look by adding in what made WWII a very dangerous time, and visiting and/or fighting in foreign countries.  Jerry Goldsmith finds the right time to use his score, which captures the mood of each scene to a fault.  Fred J. Koenekamp shoots every scene with finesse, while Hugh S. Fowler makes the final film what it is.  The best contribution to this masterpiece is George C. Scott in the iconic role.  Though he gave up his Oscar due to him disagreeing the idea of competing, he gives one of the best performances in film history, where he's able to capture the personality, look, and characteristics of Patton, making him live the role.  Patton is able to show how brave the general is, even during the worst times in war, including base attacks, where he doesn't hesitate at bringing down the enemy, whether it not he loses his life.   A must-see, and one of the best films ever made.

In 1970, people were sick of the Vietnam War and were not interested in seeing any war movies, especially films that supported the Vietnam War (such as John Wayne's highly controversial The Green Berets). But with the release of Patton, based on the famed and controversial military leader of WWII, it got people interested, and in the end, Patton was a highly acclaimed classic and ended up winning Best Picture, beating out Airport, Five Easy Pieces, Love Story, and MASH. With a legendary performance from George C. Scott in the title role, Patton is an unforgettable movie-going experience.

General George Patton (George C. Scott) is called to lead the American troops of North Africa. After getting them into shape, he leads the troops to fight the Germans, led by German Field Marshal Rommel (Karl Micherl Volger). Afterwards, Patton races to Italy, but controversy arises when Patton intends to have competition with British officer Montgomery (Michael Bates), intending to beat him to Sicily. But Patton's biggest challenge comes after slapping one of his soldiers for being a "coward." People cried foul, and Patton nearly loses his job. But with the help of military friend  Bradley (Karl Malden), Patton takes command of the Third Army and leads them all through Europe to defeat the Nazis once and for all.

First off, I applaud director Franklin J, Schaffner and his crew for realistically portraying the war. The battle scenes are wonderfully made (with no CGI), and show the dedication of the American troops and their fight for freedom. Scenes with young men killed in battle serve as moving and inspiring.

Jerry Goldsmith's score is outstanding. The now-famous trumpet echoes are highly original and leaves a lasting impact long after seeing the film. Also, the entire Patton theme is heroic and inspiring. Jerry Goldsmith is one of my favorite film composers, definitely in my Top 5, and Patton is one of his best scores, along with Planet of the Apes, The Mummy, and Star Trek: The Motion Picture.

Karl Malden plays Patton's friend Bradley, who saves Patton's reputation, and his role is well-done. I view this as Malden's finest role, not his Oscar-winning performance in A Streetcar Named Desire. The way his character sticks up for Patton is what a true friend should do, even if the two officers disagree on military tactics. ("I do it because I was trained to. You do it because you love it.")

You can't review Patton without talking about George C. Scott's portrayal of the military hero, and in my opinion, Scott's performance is phenomenal. The character of Patton is one of the most fascinating military leaders of all-time, and Scott's performance delivers. Patton is a devout Christian, but believes in reincarnation and curses out his men in  order to get them in shape. Scott's tale on the character features him in the film's most memorable moments, such as the already-mentioned soldier slapping scene, a scene where Patton prays during a montage of war in the night, and in the most famous sequence, Patton's memorable opening speech to the Third Army. ("Americans love to fight. It's in their blood.") Some of the harsher language in this scene had to be toned down in order for the film to receive a PG rating (there was no PG-13 in 1970), but either way, that speech still carries out, making Patton one of the most unforgettable experiences in Hollywood history. 

Originally, John Wayne was supposed to play Patton, but Wayne turned it down, probably due to his Vietnam controversy. John Wayne is good in his westerns, but had he played Patton, then the film would have been an epic disaster. People are born to do great things, and in the case of George C. Scott, he was born to play Patton, one of the greatest military leaders of all-time. George C. Scott won an Oscar for his role, and while he refused to accept the award, calling the Academy a "meat-market", I feel that his Oscar win was well-deserved.

But even with Scott's Oscar-winning performance, that doesn't mean that Patton is a perfect film. While Patton is a three-hour film, for me, it lacked proper character development. Even though we got to see Patton develop from a grumpy old man to a war hero, I wanted to see the character before his time in the war. I wanted to see his family life, his education, the reason why he believed in reincarnation, and how he joined the military and became a general. But in the end, I was still impressed with the film, even if I wanted to witness Patton's entire life.

It's been called the greatest war film ever made, and while I have a stronger preference to Sergeant York and The Longest Day, Patton is an unforgettable film extravaganza, with an epic Jerry Goldsmith score, a phenomenal and compelling performance from George C. Scott, and a heroic story. Say what you want about Patton, but Patton is the big reason why America still exists today. Without Patton, then the Nazis might have won, and with Scott's grand performance, everyone can witness the grand heroism of a fascinating military leader.

But he was rebellious as well as brilliant, and as Patton shows with insight and Poignance, his own volatile personality was one enemy he could never defeat.
